reviewText: It seems that lately I've become more of a casual JRPG* fan than I care to admit. Just to give an example: While my The Legend of Heroes: Trails in the Sky installation gathers cobwebs and silently weeps, I've played through three Compile Heart games. Now when I use the word casual"
date: I don't mean it in the sense of "Those filthy casuals are killing my hardcore games!" A casual game is something I play when I want to relax. Lethal RPG: War isn't much to look at
recommended: but it's a perfectly safe product for casual consumption.\n\nThe undead menace must be stopped! The main character is named Lethal and...oh...really? Lethal?! The only way this clown could be any edgier
hoursPlayed: is if he had spikey hair and an oversized sword. *ahem* Anyway
voteText: you're tasked with leading Lethal and his party on a world-saving adventure. On your journey you'll complete several quests
votesTotal: and challenge dangerous bosses. The storyline is serviceable
votesFunny: and the few instances of personality in the cast are welcome. However
commentsCount: this game can be beaten in less than 10 hours
column16: so don't expect much in the way of extensive character arcs. The guy who tells dumb jokes? He's staying that way. Don't expect him to stop joking and then tell everyone about his troubled past as a bandit.\n\nPart of what makes Lethal RPG a casual JRPG experience is the lack of what we're accustomed to. There is an overworld
column17: but there aren't any random encounters. There are several fixed fights all over the map
column18: and you can even choose to fight whenever you want. Grinding isn't particularly necessary
column19: because you get more than enough experience and materials
column20: from fixed-fights and solving quests. The more startling omission is the complete lack of dungeons. There are numerous locations in this game
column22: but there's nothing to explore. What usually happens is that you'll fight a battle or two
column23: and then move on. Aside from the arena
column24: there aren't any situations where you have to carefully manage your resources. Oddly enough
column25: I consider this a positive element. This game is very stream-lined
column26: which makes the idea of dungeons
column27: sound like needless padding.\n\nThe battle-system in this game is fairly solid. There are a remarkable number of characters to use
column28: and they're mostly well-balanced. Much of my strategy for the boss-fights revolves around status effects. Yep
column29: this is one of those rare JRPGs
column30: where debilitating effects actually work. Bosses afflicted by poison
column32: and bleeding can lose large chunks of HP every round. You might find it more effective to use tomes to exploit weaknesses. This can include casting spells the enemy is weak against
column33: as well as enchanting weapons with particular elements. Every party member has their own set of skills
column34: and a touch of variety is always nice. Unfortunately
column35: characters - depending on when they're introduced - can fall behind in experience. On the other hand
column36: a couple levels usually won't make a difference. I also appreciate that even the regular encounters can be dangerous. Losing a party-member during a fight with a "trash-mob" is not uncommon.\n\nUpon completion of Lethal RPG: War
column37: you're allowed to access New Game+ mode. As per genre standards
column38: this mode lets you play through the story again while carrying over all levels
column40: and equipment upgrades. This also raises the monster's experience level
column41: because it'd be too easy otherwise. It's a nice gesture
column42: but it's like prestiging in a Multiplayer FPS. All you really have is an excuse to jump back on the hamster wheel
column43: and dirty newspapers don't even get replaced. You're liable to use the same strategies for every encounter. Sure
column44: you'll have a few more options to play around with
column46: is that the numbers are much higher.\n\nAnother complaint that I have is the music. There really aren't enough tracks to go around. Actually
column47: I guess I could consider this a positive. Since the soundtrack isn't all that great
column48: it's a perfect excuse to catch up on other music or a few podcasts. Also the writing is a little too dry. Some of the NPCs will mention dramatic events
column49: but they will be stated in such a matter-of-fact manner that your only response is "Oh okay". I would have preferred a little drama
column50: give these traumatic moments time to sink in
column51: instead things just tend to happen.\n\nAwhile back I reviewed another JRPG by the name of Crystal Story II. I stated that it had a certain nebulous charm. I think the same can be said for Lethal RPG: War. The protagonist is a dork
column53: and there isn't really much to do aside from fight monsters
column56: everything in this game is endearing in its own twisted way. It's a good palette cleanser when other games get so wrapped up in themselves
column57: you forget which way is up. Maybe this also says something about my tastes. When it comes to reviewing 2D shooters and beatemups
column58: I can be very strict. With JRPGs
column59: even if they don't do much to stand out
column60: I tend to be pretty lenient. Perhaps there is a certain joy exclusive to the genre. Adventuring
column63: just feels good to me. Whatever the case
column64: I think this game is okay.\n\n*While not made in Japan
column65: Lethal RPG does have the attributes of a common JRPG.\n\nIf you liked this review or want to see more recommended games
column66: be sure to follow our curator group: Follow Original Curator Group"

reviewText: Lethal RPG: War may well be quite competitive as compared to free flash games in terms of its story, graphics, and gameplay, but there's just not enough there to make this a game I would recommend.\n\nFirst up, the story is stupid, and not even in a so bad it's good" way
date: most of the time. It takes itself quite seriously
recommended: despite having a main character named Lethal
hoursPlayed: but the plot is incredibly generic "save the kingdom from the creepy crawlies
voteText:
so there's very little there to really either catch a player's interest or amuse a player who's playing it for laughs.

The main issue is the gameplay, though. The game is very, very grindy insofar as you will be repeating more or less similar strategies dozens of times, given that even generic enemies are tough enough that essentially all fights will take 4+ rounds to resolve, even those you're sure you'll win from the start.  (Actually, as a sidenote, generic enemies encountered in random battles seemed stronger than generic enemies encountered in story battles. This is probably an artifact of the level scaling, but it still contributed to the grindy feeling.) This is compounded by a system where enemies scale to Lethal's level (to a minimum and maximum based on the map area you're in) but your characters don't gain full XP unless they're in the active party, meaning that not picking two companions - and on a first run, almost certainly the two you start with - and sticking with them through the entire game is a recipe for a needlessly difficult time.

As upsides, the graphics are actually pretty well done and the actual combat mechanics are fairly interesting for important fights - each character has a basic attack, a defensive move, up to five special attacks unlocked as they level up, and a wide selection of spells and consumable items acquired during the course of the game. Just... there's not much other than those boss fights, which can vary wildly in difficulty, to really act as a draw for this RPG.

So yeah, no. Lethal RPG: War's solidly mediocre in a way that makes it not a game I'd recommend to anyone in particular.

reviewText:
Lethal RPG: War is a very enjoyable little RPG.

Pros:
Low price.
The art is well done. If you like cartoon style sprites, it looks great in HD.
It feels challenging, even on normal difficulty.
The pet system is simple to use, and there's over 20 pets to collect.
If you're an achievement hunter it's pretty easy to 100%.
Cons:
The story is not bad, but it's probably one that's been told a thousand times over.
I usually enjoy playing with paladins, but the paladin in Lethal RPG: War is a bit unbalanced and by far the weakest character.
Overall it's worth playing.

reviewText:
I've thoroughly enjoyed this game. As a fan of RPGs with turn-based combat, I can certainly recommend it. The fighting was very strategic and for the most part I found it balanced well enough to stay challenging but not impossible. You acquire several party members throughout the game and can change them in and out of the active party any time between battles. There is a great variety of allies, though I personally found all of the mage types to be too mushy and die too easily to enemy attacks, so I ended up using mostly the fighter types throughout most of the game.

The combat in general was great, but there were a few things that annoyed me. One aspect in particular was that enemies virtually always had better agility than my team, so they always took their actions first every turn, which meant that if any of your allies got low on health, they'd be finished off the next turn before you get a chance to heal them. The only times the enemy agility was equal to agility of my allies was when I was overlevelled for the area. Even the assassin (the fastest party member) wouldn't always go before the enemy.

Another annoyance mostly came in late stages of the game. A lot of the enemies and bosses later on just started having way too many resistances, so you'd often end up dealing very little damage to them if only 1 party member had the means to strike their weakness, and hence the battles were dragging out. Without giving any spoilers, I found the final boss to be very uninteresting, due to that same fact. He was only weak to one element, which only the main character could use, what meant that your 2 other allies in the party were only useful for serving potions and dealing an occasional debuff on the boss.

The first half of the game was really great. It only started to get a bit repetitive later on, and I feel it could've easily been 2-3 areas shorter. Just feels that it overstayed its welcome a bit.

I imagine the art style won't be to everyone's liking, but I personally thought it was nice-looking and thought it gave a nice flare to the tone of the game. Since the game was rather light-hearted and even cheesy, the visuals fit it fine. The music was also great. Even though there were only about half a dozen of tunes in the entire game, I never really got bored of hearing them, since they were pleasing to the ear.

There wasn't much else happening aside from battles, although I did enjoy the crafting mechanic. Each character had 4 possible armours and 4 possible weapons to craft throughout the game, and each one could be upgraded. In addition to weapons and armour, you can also find a variety of animals to serve as the main character's pet. Each animal had different strengths and weaknesses, so some degree of micro-management was needed to make them useful in battles.

The story is pretty much your cheesy light-hearted epic fantasy. It doesn't do anything extraordinary, but it's there to make the game a bit more fun.

Overall it's a fun game and I enjoyed it.

reviewText:
Pros:
+Turn-based combat
+Surprisingly fun
+Combat  and enemy designs are interesting
+Lengthy story.

Cons:
-Combat can range from frustratingly difficult to absurdly easy within a battle or two
-No random encounters
-Story is cliche-riddled and very derivative
-Attempts at humor fall VERY flat

I've played about 6 hours so far, and have to say that I enjoy it. Despite its flaws, it's a very fun little RPG. The story, characters and situations may be derivitave, but the game rushes you from one arc to the next that you'll hardly notice, and simply get caught up in slaying zombies, dragons, orcs, werewolves, leveling your characters and crafting stronger weapons and armor.

I picked this up on sale for 0.54 cents, but I'd say that ultimately it's got enough content to be worth full price.

reviewText:
A simple but fun turn-based RPG, recommended for fans of the genre but especially those who don't mind casual play and repetitive actions/battles.

+Decent visuals and story
+Good variety of skills, magic, effects
+Pets with varied element and status effects
+Craft system for upgrading weapons, armor, pets
+Choose party characters from a growing roster as story progresses
+Some freedom to choose where to explore, side quests

-Very repetitive battles, pretty much same enemies each battle within a zone
-Incremental upgrades don't really feel much more powerful
-Menus/UI optimized more for mobile/phone than PC
-No keyboard support, lots of clicking

Overall a pretty good casual RPG, especially for the price on sale

reviewText:
tl;dr -> Played this game for a few minutes and suddenly thought I was on Kongregate. 11/10 totally-doesn't-remind-me-of-Cloud-Strife-simulator.

Cons:

-fairly simple mechanics - level-locked skills, upgrade weapons/armor for more damage/defence
-bland story
-no fast-forward option - combat can feel tedious after a while

Pros:

-easy to learn, basic gameplay = minimal learning curve
-minimal grinding required - if you just do all the main battles, you can beat the game; grinding is mostly for upgrading your weapons/armor
-party composition can make game easier if done correctly - for example, some bosses/enemies are weaker against magic damage, so using a mage will help immensely
-unlockable tomes add to combat choices - for example, healing tomes and weapon imbuing tomes can buff your party
-unlockable pets add an extra attack (sometimes elemental) to most of your main character's (Lethal)

If you are very interested in this type of game, then you will get at least a few hours worth of playtime for a fair asking price. Note, there are many similar games to play for free on Flash websites like Kongregate.

Recommend!

Cheers,
DJSF @DJSF's Rogue Reviews

My Website[theroguereviews.com]

reviewText:
I dont usually like turn-based party RPGs, but I liked this.

I got about 16 hours out of it, for the perfect game - but you can Game+ it when finished which allows you to continue to level and upgrade your items beyond the stage 10 lock you have in the first play.

I honestly wont continue, as I would rather move on to another achievement game... but if you need something casual that you could beat a few times - this could be a good choice. I more than got my monies worth out of it.

Graphically, its very flash level. Not amazing, but decent enough for what it needed to do. The fights get old, and once you have a plan for the area you are in - you pretty much do the same thing until you leave - 15 fights or so. So its less about all the choices you have and more about not using things you currently shouldn't. There is enough in the way of tomes and skills to experiment and I think its complete and balanced enough. Mid-game I did stop changing my party around tho, which always makes me wish for larger parties... but 3v3 was the concept.

The story had me laugh a few times but overall its typical of the flash rpg genre. Not overly amazing and using the skip (which I didn't) wouldn't change much. The conversations were not always that good.

I would have liked more achievements, but they were paced out very well such that there was always one in sight. For that reason I was encouraged to complete the game in a steady swoop, which is always a sign of decent achievement design.

Technically, the game played flawlessly even over many hours. I did not experience any issues of any kind, which has not been the case with many other titles lately, so that was refreshing.

TLDR: Its a nice simple RPG thats forgiving and playable. I would like to see more achievements but will be watching the dev page for more like this in the future.

reviewText:
This is an excellent throwback turn-based RPG with a good storyline. The undead are taking over and as the king's right-hand man you are tasked with making things right again. You'll meet many people along the way and recruit several of them to join you in your mission. I've had a lot of fun saving the world from necromancy.

Pros:Turn-based RPG goodness with fun cartoonish graphics
Upgradable weapons and armor via earned items from battle
Several characters available (once unlocked) to allow various combos and play styles
Dialogue that is amusing (at times) amongst the characters
Cons:Can only have 3 active party members
Grinding may be required (though I'm not sure this is actually a con since it's a turn-based RPG)
Battles are often heavily influenced by you having the right element equipped
For the money it's absolutely worth the purchase, though I wish it was a longer game.

reviewText:
Considering Lethal RPG's origins as a Flash game, it's actually pretty darn good but it's one patch away from being great.

You're given eight playable characters to add to your team.  However, only a small number of combinations are actually worthwhile.  For instance, having the mage in your team is absolutely essential.  I found the solider, berzerker, and assassin to be of far less utility.

There's a nifty crafting system that's driven by loot from tons of optional bosses and sidequests.  Upgrading your equipment visually changes your characters, which is a nice touch on a game at this price point.  Yet, the distrubtion of crafting items is frustrating.  The game desperately needs some manner of exchanging crafting supplies, especially since the money you earn by completing battles is nearly useless.  For instance, by the end of the game I had several hundred leathers but had to spend significant time grinding for linen and silk for the necromancer and mage.

The random encounters are too difficult and the bosses are (for the most part) too easy.  It shouldn't take 8-10 rounds to decide the outcome of a random encounter.  One the up side, the encounters are placed on the map so you get to decide when and where you fight.   The boss encounters are much easier and generally follow the same formula: stack DoTs, heal and regen mana.  The bosses telegraph big attacks a turn or two in advance, so throw in a well-time defend command now and then.  The multitude of bosses look cool and are animated well but don't differ significantly in strategy.

It sounds like I'm being harsh on the game but I really did enjoy it a great deal.  It was a nice break from the generic RPG Maker games that litter Steam.  If you're looking for a low-priced RPG to kill a weekend on, this is it.

reviewText: So i beat this game twice, it gets harder after the first time. The game is fun for some time but you will soon learn you can only use 3 champions to beat the game after the second time. you have to use the same 1 skill attack every fight, EVERY FIGHT! This game makes you think at first, but then you just use the same 3 skills every fight. i was even 20 levels above the zone area. Mobs would still 1 shot me, you have to just keep using smoke bombs till u get a good order of MOBS (archers, mages are easiest to kill)

reviewText: I do like this game, but your characters really do not get a lot of mp. It's a pain that I have to spam mana potions so often. I also cannot really tell the difference in the skill/difficulty level of the three difficulty settings. It also sucks that it's not possible to flee the boss fights. Some of the bosses were surprisingly easy, but at least one is pretty much impossible to beat early on. I had no way of knowing this before hand. [Edit: okay, if I would have looked at the map, I would have known, so it's my fault :3]\n\nGriping aside, I do enjoy the combat and being able to upgrade my gear/weapons. This is overall a pretty decent game.

reviewText:
Being an avid fan of the Lethal RPG series I've played all that I could. This game seems to harken back to the earlier games, in both it's gameplay, and timeline in the game itself.

IF you have played the other games in the series, I recommend you give this one a go, it may take some time to finish but it's a game you will find refreshing, given that unlike OTHER RPGs you heal between battles without needing to rest in town.

If you're not a Lethal RPG series fan, you may wanna try some of the other games first as this one is fairly basic comparitively.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Lethal RPG is an indie jRPG style. If you are curious it is actually a part of an indie franchise called Lethal.
The original version of this game is made using flash and it's free to play. Just google it.

- The game is very linear. With point-to-point movement ala Agarest War.
- About 90% the game you will be battling monster over and over and over and over and over again. And over again.
- Lots of grinding involved, mainly for material for upgrading your equipment.
- The game has turn based battle system and sideview battle.
- Battle animation kinda clunky but somehow i like it because it looks funny.
- A very challenging New Game +.
- ♥♥♥♥♥♥ autosave that you can't disable. Messed up my save file thx to this.

The game is decent, short and pretty enjoyable on short play sessions.
Although depending on your expectations you might be disappointed with the game.

The game is cheap, but i recommend to buy the game only when it's on a sale.
Mainly because there are better games with the same price tag.

Or maybe just play the free flash version if you're stingy.

reviewText: To be completely honest, this game is far better than I expected and I am truly enjoying my time playing it.  I truly do suggest this game for those who are interested in turn based RPGs.  The fact that you are at full health and your dead characters are revived after each round is just truly nice to have for once.\n\nYeah....I suggest getting this game and I sorta feel bad for being able to get it in a bundle but I would gladly have bought it if it wasn't knowing how it plays is all.

reviewText:
I got this game for 4-bits. If you want to pay 10x that at normal  price. That's your choice.

Pros
-It's a standard  JRPG game. If you've played any of that type of game before it'll be easy to play with little to no problem.
-There isn't flash, flare and other such gimmics in the game. No slot machine large numbers that are used  to make it seem like you're doing big damage when you really aren't.
-Decent music and sound efects.
-I didn't notice any problems running the game.

Cons
-As with most games of this type there's no options to speak of. Volume, fullscreen and dif is all. Well, music slider too.
-The curser is decktop and the names for items aren't outline in a bold boarder. This could be a problem for those of you (like me) who have eye disorders.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=693243074
